simplified: Dreams show your thoughts. Common dreams are about flying, falling, losing teeth, or being without clothes in public. These dreams mean the same thing for many people. To understand them, think about your day and how you feel.

Wild dogs in Moscow are an interesting example of wild animals living in a city. About 35,000 dogs live on the streets there. Some were born wild, others were left by their owners. Some live alone, some live in groups. In 2010, scientists studied them. They found that the dogs adapted well to city life. The dogs know it's safer to cross the street with people. Some even understand traffic lights.

Wonder is a first book by R.J. Palacio. She tells the idea came from seeing a girl with face differences on the street. The book became very popular in the USA and won many prizes. Schools use it to talk about being kind to others and friendship. A movie is being made, and many are waiting for her next book.

Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. She knows rats are not normal pets. She has tried to explain many times that rats are not dirty. They are great pets if you take care of them. Some people do not like rats. Chloe did not like them until she saw Martin's pet rats. She saw they were cute and smart. Last year, one of Martin's rats had babies. Chloe decided to take two from Martin.

Cape Town is dangerous for baboons. Some are hurt/killed in car accidents. Others get electric shocks from wires. Fewer and fewer baboons live there now. The city hires people to save them. The team follows baboons, takes them to the countryside. The plan works a little. Baboons come back because they find food in the city.

I work for an international IT company. I work from home because my company's main office is in the USA. I don't go to work every day. I work on different projects. This system helps me because I can take time off when my kids need me for school shows or when I need to see a dentist. The problem is that I don't have fixed work hours. I often work late in the evening and sometimes miss dinner to finish my work.

In the 1990s, graffiti stayed popular. Street art grew a lot around the world. Some artists wanted to show political messages about wars and problems like unfair treatment. Others made pretty and colorful art. In South America, many artists painted in poor areas. They added color and beauty to boring city walls.

Social media, shops, and magazines show people many things to buy every day. People in Britain now buy more clothes and shoes than before. Online shopping makes it easy to buy things quickly. Big brands sell very cheap clothes that people wear only a few times and then throw away.

Sam narrowed his eyes at the sun. A car made a dust trail going to the Big House. The horses kicked and moved their tails. They did not care about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr. Carter only came out when he had to. That was fine for Sam. Staying away from his boss meant he kept his job. Mr. Carter wiped the sweat from his neck. His wet shirt had dark shapes like a map. His skin turned red in the June sun. He had a pale tan like someone who makes money while others do work.

People in Berlin, Germany did not agree about shooting pigs. Hunters and animal lovers argued. The city council used peaceful actions instead. They built fences and made feeding pigs not allowed. They do not know if this works. Warmer winters bring more pigs now.

The Hunger Games book gets some ideas from old Greek stories. Suzanne liked the story of Theseus and the Minotaur when she was young. Athens is under Crete's rule, but the people of Athens stop following the rules. King Minos of Crete asks Athens to send 7 boys and 7 girls every year. The children go to a maze and are eaten by the Minotaur. A boy named Theseus goes to the maze. He kills the Minotaur. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a hero from the future, like Theseus.

Zoos connect people and animals. They can teach people how to protect animals and their homes. Some zoos are safe places for animals that were mistreated or for pets that were abandoned. Zoos also do research on animal behavior and how to treat illnesses.

A new trend is starting to fight buying too much – the Buy Nothing trend. It began in Canada in the 1990s and came to the US. People stop buying on Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving. On Buy Nothing Day, they do protests and cut up credit cards. Buy Nothing groups also share and fix items they already have all year.

Is graffiti art or crime? It depends on where you live. In many places, painting on buildings or others' things is a crime. Some street artists get caught by police and pay fines. Cities spend much money to clean walls, buses and trains from graffiti.

More people now see street art as real art. Big shows have happened in Paris, London, and Los Angeles. In 2008, Elura Emerald, an American artist, held a street art show in New York. She said: 'Street artists are just sharing their art and not harming anyone. People should enjoy their work and praise them.'

Most people have 4-6 dreams each night after age 10. This means about 2,000 dreams per year. By age 80, people may have around 140,000 dreams. We forget almost all our dreams, but we remember a few thousand. It's normal for a dream to match real events sometimes, especially if the dream topic is part of daily life.

The Hunger Games happens in the future after North America is destroyed. The country is called Panem, with twelve poor areas ruled by the rich Capitol. The Capitol has complete power. Each area makes something for the Capitol. District 12, where the story starts, makes coal. There was a thirteenth area, but they rebelled against the Capitol long ago and were destroyed.

Wild animals come to cities for food. In Cape Town, baboons now come to houses near the city. They open trash bins, eat garden fruit, and enter homes! Brave baboons take food from kitchen shelves and fridge. Baboons are mean and attack pets - this makes people angry.
Many bridge accidents happen while building the bridge. Engineers sometimes make mistakes, like wrong calculations. The bridge can fall down. This is very dangerous for workers building it.

George Lucas was a movie maker. His stories follow the hero's journey. This journey has 17 parts. At first, the hero lives a simple life. Then, something happens to start the adventure. In Star Wars, Luke lives with his aunt and uncle. He fixes robots. He finds a secret message in R2D2. The message is from Princess Leia. This is Luke's call to adventure.

One way to stop a big rock from hitting Earth is to use a nuclear bomb. This idea was in a movie from 1998. NASA has a real plan called HAMMER. The plan uses very big rockets (eight tons) to hit a rock coming close to Earth. The rockets try to change the rock's direction. If the rock is too close, the rockets carry bombs to explode it.

Campbell says the hero first does not want to go on an adventure. Then a teacher gives help. The hero leaves home and enters a new place. In this new place, the hero meets friends, fights bad people, and takes tests to get ready for the biggest problem. For Luke, the teacher is Obi-Wan. His friends are Han Solo, R2D2, and C3PO. The big bad person is Darth Vader. Important events happen on the Death Star.

Some things are not used often. They can help others. The internet helps people earn money by sharing these things. Websites and apps make it easy to buy and sell old items. This sharing is called the sharing economy.

During the 1700s and 1800s, people had two ideas about dreams. One idea: dreams show hidden thoughts. Freud said dreams help you know your hidden feelings and why you feel sad or worried. The other idea says dreams are just mixed-up brain activity. The brain is sorting memories and daily events. When you wake up, you make stories from these jumbled images and feelings.

NASA needs money to build a space telescope called NEOCam. This telescope uses special light to find asteroids near Earth. If NASA gets the money, they can finish it in ten years. Then, the team that protects Earth will need to find ways to stop dangerous asteroids like PHAs.

Some famous people on social media who usually talk about clothes and makeup are now telling others not to buy anything for a year. In Canada, two friends tried to buy only food for a year. For the first three months, they stopped buying things for the home, electric things, and clothes. Then, they stopped getting haircuts, eating at restaurants, or buying gas for their car. In the end, they saved $55,000.

Religion is important for Pi. His family is Hindu, but Pi is interested in other religions. He becomes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. Everyone is surprised when Pi says he is Hindu, Muslim, and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to pick only one religion, he says no. He says, 'I only want to love God.' After that, they let him decide on his own.

Some people say writing about dreams helps you realize you are dreaming. When you know you are dreaming, you can decide what happens. You can make a scary dream into a happy one, or guide the dream like a director. Instead of just thinking about dream meanings, you can make your own dreams. But you might still want some dreams that show what your mind is thinking!

People may not know they help cause clothes problems by giving old clothes to charities. Charity shops can't sell all these clothes. Fast fashion clothes are only new for a little time. They are too poor quality to recycle and not wanted as second-hand. Many clothes get thrown away. Some go to other countries. This causes more money and environment problems there.

Some adventurers don't stop after one great trip. Meagan from Canada climbed the highest mountains on each continent, biked across Canada, and ran in the Sahara Desert when it was 45°C. Her most special journey was a ski trip to the South Pole. On day one, she fell into ice and needed help. Many people would stop there, but Meagan kept going. After 40 days, she reached the South Pole. She pulled her sled with a tent and food through cold weather and icy storms.
Blek le Rat paints rats on Paris walls. He paints people without homes in big cities. He wants people to think about the problem of not having a home.

In some areas, city leaders allow artists to paint only in special places. Taiwan has these special places called 'graffiti zones'. In Brazil, city leaders allow artists to paint on trains. This keeps graffiti legal and safe.

Faith47 is from Cape Town. She paints big, colorful pictures of people and animals. She likes to paint in different places. Her art is on the ground, in old factories, and on old cars. She likes that street art is not permanent. It changes when weather or cleaners remove it. This shows that life has changes, with things ending and new things starting.

{answer": "Gabriela worked in a place where leaders made all big decisions, and people respected authority. In this environment, workers followed instructions without questioning. Her Swedish team worked differently. They often discussed ideas together with bosses to solve problems. In this setting, leaders acted like coaches who encouraged people to think for themselves and ask questions."
}

Gabriela noticed her team worked differently. She talked to them about leading the team. Her team said they did not like being told what to do. They wanted more freedom and creativity. When Gabriela told them what to do, they felt she didn't trust them. She thought they were arguing with her. They explained it was their usual way of working.
Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint tags and big, colorful pictures on building walls. They use cranes when they paint big areas. In 2007, they painted a whole castle in Scotland.

People painted and wrote on walls for many years. Long ago, people in Africa and Europe drew animal and person pictures in caves. Graffiti was found in old buildings in Greece, Italy, Syria, and Iraq. In Pompeii, archaeologists found graffiti in Latin. The messages wrote about religion, politics, love, and magic spells.

Do you imagine climbing Mount Everest or going to the South Pole? Many people try these big adventures each year. Thousands climb very high mountains or walk across large land areas. In the past, explorers used maps and compasses for directions. Now, adventurers use GPS and satellite phones to find their way. Some adventurers love nature and use their trips to tell others about problems in the environment. Others help people in need and collect money for charities.

DART is a test mission for an asteroid called Didymos. Didymoon is 150 meters wide. It goes around a bigger asteroid that is 800 meters wide. Scientists will send DART to hit Didymoon. They hope the collision will change Didymoon's path so telescopes on Earth can see the change.

The main character is a 16-year-old girl named Katniss. Her father died in a mine accident. She must feed her family. Katniss hunts in the forest near her home with her friend Gale. She becomes good at using a bow and arrow. When her younger sister Prim is chosen for a competition, Katniss agrees to go instead. The other participant from her area is a boy named Peeta. Katniss and Peeta have a difficult relationship.

Write about your dreams. This helps you remember more details. Think about the people and places in the dream. They can help you understand better. After one week, you will see how much you have written. Now, link your dreams to things and feelings in your daily life.

Long ago, bridges were often made of wood. They caught fire easily. Old train bridges had this problem too. Sparks from train wheels on tracks sometimes started fires. Then the bridges burned down completely.

We cannot know the future of street art. Some trends are beginning. Most street artists are young. They paint in their city or neighborhood. More artists are now traveling and working all around the world. They use the internet to speak and show their pictures. Many museums and galleries are showing street art. It is becoming a real art form. We don't know what will happen next. But it will stay because people like it.

Suzanne Collines was never happy watching war news. When she was a child, her father was a US Air Force pilot who went to Vietnam. Her mother tried to keep her safe by not telling her about the war. Suzanne still saw the news and knew her dad was in Vietnam. That time was very scary for her.

A big survey by PwC asked more than 40,000 millennials and older workers about their thoughts on work culture, how they communicate, job styles, how much money they get for their jobs, career growth, and work-life balance. Deloitte did another survey with 10,000 millennials. They asked about problems and chances in the current work environment.

Erik Weihenmayer is from the US. He is an adventurer. He rode a bike in Morocco's deserts. He went kayaking in the Grand Canyon. He climbed Everest. He became blind at 13 years old. Erik helps disabled people stay active. He takes young blind people on climbing trips.
Online shops help people make money fast. Before, busy parents could not sell old baby clothes at markets. Now, they can sell baby clothes, buggies, and toys online. This helps them get money back.

Pi and Richard Parker stay in a small boat for 227 days. They face hunger, sickness, and tiredness. They face strong storms and hot sun in the Pacific, but they survive. Sometimes Pi feels comfort from his religions. Sometimes he feels very lonely and sad. One day, the Mexican coast appears. Everything changes. To know what happens when they reach land, read the book. It is better not to tell the ending here.

Chloe came home from school. She made a cup of coffee and took it to her bedroom. She had homework, but she would do it later. She liked the quiet time before her parents came home. The house was usually noisy in the evening with talk, TV, or her dad's jazz music while he cooked. She also liked playing with her pet rats during this time.

In 2010, NASA found and recorded 90% of the big rocks near Earth that are 1km wide. These rocks are called 'near-Earth objects' or 'NEOs'. They are as big as mountains and can come within 50 million km of Earth's path around the sun. NASA thinks there are about 50 more to find, and none of the 887 they know are a big risk to Earth.

Auggie starts school. He feels very worried on the first day. Other kids avoid him because he looks different. No one sits near him, and they stare or whisper. He makes friends with Jack and Summer. But some students avoid touching him, afraid he might have a serious illness. During the school year, Auggie has many happy and sad moments. A scary event at camp changes everything for him.

The two men looked at the north side of the place. The land went on forever. You couldn't see the fences clearly from where they stood. He might feel bored and want to run away, but he couldn't leave on foot. Sam watched the big horse. It kicked the ground with big feet. 'Can the boy ride?' Sam asked. A good rider could find problems here. It is a long way from people. Someone who doesn't know horses and runs from his father might get more problems here.

More than 4,000 climbers, from 13 to 80 years old, have reached the top of Everest. Climbing high mountains in very cold weather and strong storms is still very dangerous. The best climbers now want new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria loved mountain climbing since she was young. After she finished school, she worked as a nurse. But she continued to climb in her free time.

After climbing Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world's 8,000 metre peaks. She makes it harder by not using oxygen tanks. This is dangerous because the top of high mountains has very little oxygen, which is bad for the brain and body. Gerlinde uses her fame to help poor children and orphans in Nepal.

If you look at things you bought, you will see that some are not used. For example, you might have a warm coat you like but live in a hot country. You may keep an old phone after buying a new one. Your car may only go out on weekends. Your guest room may now be a storage room. Not all your things are used well all the time.
Dreams have always been linked to prophecy in many cultures. People believed dreams were messages from gods to share knowledge. Today, many people remember dreams that became true later.

Big transport projects often build bridges. Bridges carry cars, trucks, and trains over water, mountains, or roads. They are very important for building. People check them carefully when they fall down.

Gabriela wrote an email to her Swedish manager. She had problems with her team. The manager asked, 'Is your team still doing well? What can help you work better with your team?' Gabriela found the manager not clear. She felt he wasn't helping enough.

Dogs in groups learn people give food to small, cute dogs. These dogs ask for food for the group. They use the metro train to travel. Scientists don't know how they find the right stops. Maybe they smell the places they like. Or they hear station names on the train. Now, people on the metro don't notice the dogs.

Ed Stafford from the UK was the first to walk the whole way along the Amazon River. He started at a small stream in the Andes Mountains in Peru. It took him two years and four months. He walked 6,000 kilometers. The Amazon rainforest has dangerous animals like snakes, crocodiles, and jaguars. Ed was always in danger. He survived with many mosquito and ant bites. He was lucky to stay alive.

In Britain, most people spend over £1,000 on clothes each year. This is about 4% of their income. This might not seem like a lot, but it shows two bigger problems. First, many people use credit cards for buying clothes. Now, adults in Britain owe around £670 to credit card companies. This is about 66% of the money they spend on clothes. Also, they are buying things they don't need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothes yearly. Most goes to landfills.

Ed could not walk without machines. He used a radio to ask rainforest people for food and permission to go through their land. Many came to meet him and helped him through the tough paths. Ed wrote a blog about his days while walking. He told news cameras about rainforest cutting and asked for money for charities in Brazil and Peru that help kids and the environment.

Companies use sharing websites to make money. These websites help people find things they need. For example, Airbnb helps people rent spare rooms. Uber helps drivers give rides using their cars. People earn money when they have free time.

Zoos help breed animals worldwide, especially those in danger. In the wild, rare animals have a hard time finding partners and having babies. They face dangers like hunters, losing where they live, or other animals. A good zoo gives them safety and helps them have babies. When wild animal populations get too low, they can become too much the same. Breeding plans protect this: animals from zoos can be put back into nature to add more different genes to help them survive.

These accidents happen very rarely. Trains and boats can make a bridge fall down because of different causes. Trains break a bridge because of the speed when they hit. Boats have a very heavy weight that can break a bridge, even if they move slowly. To avoid accidents, we should plan better. New technology finds weak parts. Safer places and stronger designs help stop accidents.

Pi is very scared of the animals. He jumps into the ocean. He thinks about the sharks in the water. He knows he must return to the lifeboat. The animals in the lifeboat fight and eat each other. Soon, only Pi and the tiger remain. The tiger is seasick. He calls the tiger Richard Parker. Richard Parker is not interested in eating Pi now.

When Pi is 16, a new government is chosen. His parents don't like them. They worry about the future and close the zoo. They sell animals to North American zoos and take a ship to Canada. A big storm hits, and the ship goes down. Pi's family and the sailors die, but Pi is in a lifeboat with a hyena, a zebra, an orang-utan, and a big tiger.

The Hunger Games is a very popular book for teens and young adults written by American author Suzanne Collins. It was published in 2008 and has been translated into 26 languages. The book sold millions of copies worldwide. It was the first book for young readers to sell over one million digital copies. The Hunger Games is now a big Hollywood movie that is equally popular. The movie earned $152.5 million in its first weekend in North America alone.

Dreams may happen when our brain organizes daily thoughts. When awake, we think in words, like talking to ourselves. When asleep, the brain part for language works less, and the part for emotions works more.

Good relationships help make life happy. A study found happy people have close family and friends. They meet often. One friend to talk about feelings without holding back is important. This friend can share with other friends too. Just having many friends for fun or talking about music/games is not enough. Real talk about important things is most important. Learning to listen carefully helps make stronger friendships.

Carol Dweck is a psychologist. She says our brain can change and get better. We can learn new skills or improve things we already know. Many people praise when something is done well. They say things like, 'You are good at details' or 'You are good at organizing events.' But research says it's better to praise how someone works. Encourage trying, working hard, and finding ways to solve problems. This helps people learn and get better at new things.

The rover checks the air around it sometimes. In 2014, it found a simple molecule and a gas called methane. Methane is part of natural gas. Methane doesn't stay in the air for very long. It lasts maybe a few hundred years. This means something on Mars makes new methane. NASA says Mars releases methane in big amounts. Methane levels change with seasons, like the planet is breathing.

Carol Dweck, a psychologist from Stanford, gave ten-year-olds problems too hard to solve. One group said they liked challenges and wanted to get better. She called this a 'growth mindset.' These kids think about what they can do in the future. Other children said they failed forever. She called this a 'fixed mindset.' Some said they might cheat next time. Others looked at students who did worse to feel better.

Horror films use empty or old places. They could be an old hospital, an empty house, or a town with no people. When people lived there, what was there? Why did they leave? Maybe because these places are very quiet. That can also be scary. Old places are useful for horror directors because no one can get a phone signal there.

In any house, the basement is scary in horror movies. Things hide there. Evil people keep their tools in the basement. They are always dark and sometimes wet. You use a small and narrow stairs to get to them. Basements feel spooky even when empty.

Gary Collins, a policeman not at work, saw the London riots on TV. He knew many people in the video. So he ended his vacation early to help identify them. Gary watched 200,000 hours of CCTV for six months. He found 190 people, often just by looking at their eyes. His help was very important for the investigation. A computer program found only one person.

I find it interesting how we can improve our bodies. Imagine putting a computer in our brain! Soon, we can do this. It will help us with math, seeing and hearing better, and remembering things. This idea will become more common.

The talk was good. The speaker had good ideas. For example, parents use phones when cooking or waiting. They use them a lot. How can they tell teenagers not to text when parents do this too? The speaker also said people try to be in many places. They talk in real life and on the internet. This happens with my teenage daughter and her friends. They make plans to meet, but sit together quietly. Each friend uses their phone for different internet chats.

Sometimes news makes us think the world is more violent, but there are also good things. After WWII until 1990, about 30 wars killed over 100,000 people each. Now, there are still some wars, but many countries live in peace more than before. However, terrorism has increased a lot in recent years. Wars since WWII killed more regular people than soldiers. For regular people, things are not all bad. Violent crime causes more deaths than war, but murder rates were lower in 2015 than in 2000 (5.3 vs 8 per 100,000 people).

Wasfia has spent her life helping human rights. She has seen many international projects in Bangladesh that teach and help women and girls. Often, these projects end and women get nothing. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to help itself. She connected her love for climbing mountains and human rights to change how people see women. She started climbing while working in Tibet and Nepal. In Bangladesh, a flat country, few people see mountains. Now, her work is working - people in Bangladesh and others are paying attention.

Most people think developing countries are very poor, have leaders who control too much, and have no hope for change. But this is not true. Big changes are happening. In the last 20 years, over 700 million people earned more money and left poverty. Fewer children die from illness every year, many more girls go to school, and many more have clean water.

Managers put good comments before and after bad feedback to make it feel better. But when they do this every time, workers may believe the good comments are just to cover up the bad news. This makes the good comments not as helpful. Instead, give good comments to really encourage great work, not only to hide bad points.

I help try to stop killer robots. Don't think about scary robots from movies. Right now, war machines like drones and robot guards can kill people with little human help. Soon, maybe robots will choose to kill without help. I think this is very dangerous and wrong for people. We must be careful about what we tell machines to do.

Many people learn English. English is spoken in more countries than other languages. However, Chinese has the most native speakers. The number of native speakers is not closely linked to the number of learners. But the number of learners is connected to how many countries have speakers.

Your manager stops you and wants to talk about your work on the new project. You think about it all weekend and worry you may have done something wrong. On Monday morning in her office, she first says good things about your work. Then she tells you the real message. Then she says nice things again. This is a common way to give feedback.

This rock album has fast and loud music. The songs have simple words but big emotions. They talk about sad stories from the American dream. Regular workers find life hard. They work a lot but get no money or fame. People feel sad and angry when life gives them nothing. Glory Days: Small town people remember when they were young and had chances to be great. Downbound Train: A young man loses his job, life turns bad. The singer uses real people's stories. He guesses his own life if he wasn't famous. The Boss is very talented.

Lewis wants more protected areas for the sea. Right now, only 3% are protected. He thinks increasing it to 10% will help stop problems like too much fishing, pollution, and trash. He has seen these problems while traveling. He saw white coral reefs and places in the Red Sea with no life and lots of plastic. Pugh says if we let nature rest, it can get better. But time is running out. We must protect our seas now, or a big problem will come.

Terrie Sharp is a popular author. She writes exciting stories. She won the Olive Crime Writer Award. She won it two times. She grew up in Glasgow. The area was very dangerous. Crime was high there. She learned to stay out of trouble. She learned how to open car doors with a knife. She uses these things for her books. She appears on TV. She is on shows like Police Today. She gives talks at writing events. The events are all over the UK.

Is life worse each day? Can we improve? Steven Pinker's 'Enlightenment Now' says today, people live longer, healthier, and freer. He says science and reason are not used properly. Some leaders and shows tell people to stay with their group, believe nothing changes, or not trust experts. This breaks important systems like democracy and countries helping each other.

In early scary movies, when bad things happened, the main characters could not ask for help or call the police. Now, mobile phones make this story less true. How to keep the scary feeling? No signal on the phone! When you are the hero, at a very important time, your phone will not work. The battery may be out, or there is no signal. Maybe both happen.

In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America lost their main banana, 'Big Mike.' Now, the same problem is happening to the new banana, 'Cavendish.' Big Mike was easy to transport and tasty. United Fruit, the big banana company, grew them quickly by taking plant parts instead of using seeds. They planted the bananas very close together.

Most spiders have venom to catch prey, not hurt people. Only 25 spider types can harm humans. Spider bites hurt but are not often deadly. In Australia, the Sydney funnel-web spider hasn't killed anyone since 1981. But be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. If they feel scared, they shoot hairs that stick to skin or eyes.

This common horror movie idea was very popular in the 1900s. It shows teenagers having fun at the start, and all but one girl die by the end. At the beginning, the girl is kind and shy. In the end, she becomes strong and clever, and usually survives the horror.

To learn about where complex language comes from, look at how human brains are different from animals. Brain size alone is not enough. We need to know what other things brains can do, when and why they started. We have few clues. Old objects from our ancestors do not show what sounds they made. We can see changes in their mouth, throat, and tongue. About 100,000 years ago, people could make complex sounds. Before that, we do not know if they made simple sounds.

Society tells us girls should like art, literature, and history. Boys are expected to do math and science. We don't see many women in science jobs as good examples. TV shows and books often make male scientists, inventors, or astronauts as funny or super smart. Some people say scientists are strange, can't talk to others well, and work alone. These are not true. But this might stop girls from wanting to be scientists. If we show more women in science, girls may feel better about these subjects.

The Scallion is a weekly newspaper given free to students in university buildings. About 10,000 students read it. Students write and make it. A survey shows that students and teachers like it for fun, learning about culture, and getting work practice. Printing costs are high. Some students cannot get the newspaper easily because they must go to the university to pick it up. Too many papers become waste on campus.

At Girox Foods, about 12% of workers leave every year. This is more than the normal 7% in our industry. We want to find out why workers are not happy. Then, we will give simple ideas to make the work place better. These changes can help keep workers from leaving.

The speaker was right. If we use technology too much, we may feel lonely. This is not a problem for my generation. We know how to be alone and it's okay. People under 20 are very different. They always talk online and never feel alone. They may not learn to like being alone. They also learn to talk through messages they can change. They miss learning real talking with people nearby.
Don't give bad after good. If you mix them too often, people might not see the good. Give good alone sometimes. Don't always add advice.

Dreams can show you information about things you didn't know your brain was thinking. Common dreams like flying, falling, losing teeth or going without clothes in public usually have similar meanings for most people. The important thing is to link these dreams to the things and emotions you experience every day.

Moscow has about 35,000 wild dogs. Some were born in the wild, others are pets left behind. They live alone or in groups. In 2010, scientists found these dogs adapt well to city life. They learn safer street crossing with people and some seem to understand traffic lights.

Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. She knows that keeping rats as pets is unusual. Chloe can’t recall how many times she has tried to explain to others that rats are not dirty and can make excellent pets if cared for properly. She understands why people react negatively. She used to dislike rats, but her friend Martin changed her mind by showing her his pets. She saw how friendly and clever they were. Last year, one of Martin’s rats gave birth. Chloe decided she wanted two of them.

Cape Town is dangerous for baboons. Some get hurt or die in car crashes. Others get electrocuted by touching cables. Baboons are in danger of disappearing. To help them and stop problems with people, the city has a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors try to make baboons leave the city. They also catch them and take them to the countryside. The plan works a little, but baboons come back if they find food easily in the city.

I work for a technology company. The company's main office is in the United States, so I work from home online. This means I don't spend time traveling to work or talking with my work friends during breaks. My job is based on projects, and I can take time off when my kids have school plays or if I need to see the dentist. The bad thing is I often work late into the evening and sometimes miss dinner to finish tasks.

In the 1990s, graffiti kept happening, but street art grew more around the world. Some artists wanted to show opinions about politics, war, fairness, and equality through their work. Others focused on creating nice, colorful pictures. In South America, street artists painted colorful images on gray buildings in poor areas to brighten cities.

Social media, magazines, and shop windows fill people's lives with things to buy every day. British consumers are purchasing more clothes and shoes now than ever before. It is easy to buy online without really thinking, and big brands offer very cheap clothes that are often used as throwaways—worn a few times and then thrown away.

Sam squinted at the sun, watching dust behind the car as it went toward the Big House. The horses kicked and swatted flies, ignoring their owner after not seeing him in ten months. Sam waited. Mr. Carter only came out when he needed to, and Sam was fine with that. Mr. Carter wiped sweat from his neck. Wet areas on his shirt looked like lines from a map. His skin turned red in the June sun. He had a pale color from staying inside and working with no physical labor.

Many people in Berlin, Germany said shooting pigs was too cruel. Hunters and animal lovers disagreed strongly. Because of protests, the city leaders chose calmer methods. They now use fences and banned feeding pigs. It is unclear if this solution will work. Warmer winters may lead to more pigs in the future.

Suzanne Collins got an idea for The Hunger Games from Greek myths. When she was a child, she loved the story of Theseus and the Minotaur. In the story, Athens is ruled by Crete, but the people rebel. King Minos from Crete makes Athens send seven boys and seven girls each year as punishment. The kids are put into a maze where they are eaten by a monster, the Minotaur. Theseus, a young man from Athens, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen in The Hunger Games as a future version of Theseus.

Zoos connect people with animals and help raise awareness about conservation. They take in animals rescued from circuses and look after abandoned pets. Zoos also do research on animal behavior and how to treat diseases.

A different movement is appearing against consumerism – the 'buy nothing' movement. The idea started in Canada in the 1990s and then went to the US, where it became a response to spending too much during Black Friday and Cyber Monday in November. On Buy Nothing Day, people hold protests and destroy their credit cards. All year, Buy Nothing groups help each other fix and share things they already have.

Graffiti is a type of art or vandalism. It depends on your opinion. In many countries, painting on public or private property is not allowed. Some street artists get caught and must pay fines. Cities say it costs a lot of money to clean graffiti from buildings, buses and trains.

The art world is recognizing graffiti and street art more now. There have been exhibitions of such art in Paris, London, and Los Angeles. In 2008, artist Elura Emerald organized a street art exhibition in New York. She said, 'Street artists use painting to share their thoughts. Their art does not hurt people. We should respect and celebrate them.'

Most people have 4 to 6 dreams each night after age 10. This means up to 2,000 dreams yearly. By age 80, an average person could have 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95 to 99 percent of dreams, we still remember thousands over a lifetime. If the dream is about something we do regularly in daily life, we can believe it sometimes matches a real-life event by chance.

The Hunger Games takes place in the future after the destruction of North America. The country is named Panem, which has twelve poor districts ruled by the rich Capitol. The Capitol holds total control. Each district makes different products for the Capitol. The story starts in District 12, where people supply coal for the whole country. A thirteenth district existed before but was destroyed after a rebellion against the Capitol.

Wild animals often come to cities to find food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons now enter areas outside the city. They open bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons enter houses and take food from cabinets and fridges. Baboons can be aggressive. They have attacked many pets, so people in the city do not want them here.

Many bridge accidents happen while building the bridge. This is often because engineers make a mistake, like a wrong calculation. The bridge falls down because it is too heavy, and this can kill workers on the bridge.

George Lucas was one of the first directors to use the 17 stages of the hero’s journey in his story. Usually, a hero starts by living a normal life. An event happens that changes everything and makes them go on an adventure. In the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives with his aunt and uncle, fixing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message inside the robot R2D2, this event starts his adventure.

Another way to protect Earth from an asteroid headed to hit us is to destroy it with a nuclear bomb. It might sound like a movie idea, like the 1998 film 'Armageddon,' but the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a real NASA plan. Large rockets weighing eight tons would be launched at an approaching asteroid to change its path. If the asteroid is too close for this to work, the rockets could carry nuclear bombs to break it apart instead.

Campbell explains that the hero first refuses the adventure. A mentor helps them start the journey to a new world where the adventure happens. Next, the hero faces tests, fights enemies, and meets friends to prepare for the biggest challenge. Luke's mentor is Obi-Wan. His friends are Han Solo, R2D2, and C3PO. The enemy is Darth Vader. They are all in the Death Star, the new world in the story.

Unused items might look unimportant to some people, but useful for others. The internet has made it possible for online groups to sell these items and earn money. Websites and social media groups help people buy and sell used things easily. This system is called the sharing economy.

During the 1800s and 1900s, two theories about dreams became popular. One theory says dreams show things in our mind that we are not thinking about. Freud believed understanding dreams helps us know our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory says they are just random brain activity. The brain organizes memories and daily events, and we make up stories when we wake to explain these random images and feelings.

I am a freelancer and work for myself. I can choose my work and manage my time. At first, I worked from home but had trouble concentrating. There were too many distractions, like chores, making tea, and family members needing my help. Then I tried working in a café, but the Wi-Fi was slow and I drank too much coffee. Finally, I rented a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers. Wearing clothes and working in an office helped me stay focused.

NASA can find the remaining medium-sized Near-Earth objects (NEOHazards) only if they get money to build NEOCam, a space telescope that uses infrared light to detect asteroids. With funds, they might complete the mission in ten years. After recording these objects, the planetary defense team needs to develop strategies to protect Earth from the most dangerous asteroids called Potentially Hazardous Asteroids (PHAs).

The 'buy nothing' movement now includes social media influencers who often post about clothes and makeup they advise people to buy. Some YouTube stars tell their followers not to buy anything for a whole year. Two friends in Canada tried to buy only food for a year. For three months, they practiced living without buying electronics, clothes, or home items. Then they stopped using services like haircuts, eating at restaurants, or buying car fuel. After one year, they saved $55,000.

Pi’s family is Hindu, but he is interested in other religions. He becomes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, he says he is Hindu, Christian, and Muslim at the same time. His family and teachers ask him to choose one religion. Pi says, 'I just want to love God.' After this, they allow him to decide for himself.

Some people believe writing about your dreams can help you have lucid dreams. In lucid dreams, you know you are dreaming and control what happens in them. You can change a scary dream into a safe one or control the story like a director. This way, you create your dreams instead of just trying to understand them. However, you may still want to experience ordinary dreams that let your subconscious show your thoughts.

After one exciting trip, some adventurers take on more challenges. Meagan McGrath from Canada climbed the tallest mountain on every continent, cycled across Canada, and ran a long race in the Sahara when it was 45 degrees Celsius. Her most memorable trip was a skiing adventure to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and needed help. Most people would stop there, but Meagan continued. After forty days, she reached the South Pole, pulling a sled with a tent and food through cold weather and snowstorms.

Blek le Rat began painting rats on the walls in his hometown, Paris. He wants to make people think about social issues. He paints homeless people in big cities to help residents remember the problem of homelessness.

Some local governments allow artists to paint graffiti in certain areas instead of on random walls. Taiwan is one example. There, artists can paint and write on walls in special graffiti zones. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city lets selected graffiti artists paint on subway trains.

Faith47 is from Cape Town, South Africa. She paints large, colorful pictures of people and animals and often goes to different places. Her art is on sidewalks, in empty factories, and on old cars. She likes that street art is temporary and is removed by weather or city workers. This shows how life changes and has cycles of endings and new starts.

Gabriela used to work in a place where people respect authority and know their roles. In this culture, leaders decide important things and people don’t question them much. Her Swedish team works in a culture where employees and managers work together. In their culture, leaders are like coaches who support new ideas and welcome questions.

Gabriela noticed culture differences between her and her team. She decided to talk to them about how they felt about her work. Her team was happy to share their feelings. They said they didn’t like being told what to do. They wanted to take more action and be creative. When she gave them clear tasks, they felt she didn’t trust them. They saw that Gabriela felt hurt when they questioned her choices. They explained this was their usual way of working.

Os Gêmeos are identical twin artists from São Paulo. They create graffiti tags and large, colorful murals of people on building walls. Because their murals are very large, they use cranes to help them paint. In 2007, they painted an entire castle in Scotland with vibrant patterns.

People have painted and written on walls for a long time. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe drew pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient places in Greece, Italy, Syria, and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists discovered many examples of graffiti written in Latin. These included religious, political, and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!

Have you ever wanted to climb Mount Everest or walk to the South Pole? Many people try these things each year. Today, adventurers use GPS and satellite phones, not just maps and compasses. Some love nature and use their trips to tell people about environmental problems. Others help those in need and raise money for charities.

DART is the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Scientists will test DART on Didymoon, a 150-metre asteroid that orbits Didymos. Didymos is 800 metres wide. When DART hits Didymoon, it should move the asteroid a little so that telescopes on Earth can see the change.

Katherin Everdeen is a 16-year-old girl. Her father died in a mining accident, so she must provide food for her family. She hunts in the woods near District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes highly skilled with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is chosen as one of the tribute participants, Katherin volunteers to take her sister's place. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta. Katherin finds herself involved in a complex relationship with him.

Write about your dreams to remember more details. Think about the people and places in the dream, as they can help you understand its meaning. After a week, you may be surprised at how much you have written. Now, try to relate your dreams to daily events and feelings you experience.

In the past, bridges were often made of wood and caught fire more easily. This was especially true for old train bridges. Sparks from the metal wheels and tracks could sometimes cause them to catch fire and burn down completely.

It is hard to know how street art will develop in the future, but some trends are appearing. Many street artists are young people who paint in their city or area, but now more artists travel and work around the world. Others use the internet to connect and show photos of their work. Now, more people in the art world see street art as a real art form. Even though we are unsure about the future, we know street art will stay.

Suzanne Collines has always found war-related news programmes distressing. Her father, a pilot in the US Air Force, served during the Vietnam War. Although her mother kept her from learning about the war's details, Suzanne saw news coverage and realized her father was fighting there. This experience was extremely unsettling for her.

PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) did a global survey. They collected more than 40,000 answers from people born between 1983 and 1993, and others not in that generation. The survey asked about work culture, communication styles, payment, career development, and work-life balance. Deloitte also did a survey with over 10,000 millennials. They studied these people's opinions about problems and chances in today's workplaces.

Erik Weihenmayer is from the United States. He has cycled through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked in the Grand Canyon, and climbed Mount Everest. He was blind since the age of 13. Erik encourages disabled people to stay active. He takes groups of young blind people on climbing trips and supports their adventures.

Online platforms give people chances to earn money quickly. For example, busy parents could not sell old baby clothes or prams at local markets before, but now they can use online marketplaces. These sites help them sell nearly new items they no longer need, like expensive strollers and baby gear, to get some money back.

Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days on a lifeboat. They face hunger, illness, and exhaustion. They survive strong storms and the blazing sun of the Pacific. They are very tired and sick, but they stay alive. Sometimes, Pi feels comfort from his three religions. Other times, he feels lonely and sad. Finally, the Mexican coast comes into view. Everything changes when land is near. We won’t tell you the ending—you must read the book to discover what happens when they reach land.

Chloe returned home from school and made a coffee to take upstairs. She had homework to finish but chose to delay it. She enjoyed the peaceful hours before her parents returned, when the house was quiet without evening noises or her father's favorite jazz music playing while cooking. This time was special for playing with her pet rats.

In 2010, NASA's team found and recorded 90% of big asteroids near Earth. These are called Near Earth Objects (NEOs). They are as big as mountains and are 50 million kilometers from Earth's orbit around the Sun. Experts say 50 more asteroids remain to find, but none of the 887 already listed would cause serious danger to our planet.

Auggie decides to go to school and faces his first day. Like many children at a new school, he feels very nervous. Because of his appearance, the day is difficult. Other children stare at him or whisper about him with their hands over their mouths. He makes friends with Jack, a classmate, and Summer, a girl he talks to at lunch. The first day is not the only challenge. His classmates avoid touching him because they are afraid of catching 'the plague'. During the school year, Auggie has many good and bad experiences. An unexpected and sad event at a school camp changes everything.

The two men looked at the northern end of the land. The land went on for a long way. They could hardly see the fences from where they stood. Even if a teenage boy felt very bored or restless, he couldn't run away on foot. Sam watched the biggest horse kick the ground with heavy feet. He wondered if the boy could ride a horse. A rider might face many problems out here, far from other people. But someone who doesn't know horses and wants to escape his father could have even more difficulties.

More than 4,000 climbers, from teenagers to 80-year-olds, have reached the top of Everest. Although climbing tall mountains in freezing weather and strong storms is very dangerous, top climbers now seek new challenges. Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner from Austria started loving mountain climbing when she was a teenager. After she finished school, she became a nurse but continued climbing on her own time.

After climbing Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen 8,000-metre peaks in the world. She makes the challenge harder by not using oxygen tanks, which is risky because low oxygen at high altitudes can affect how your brain and body work. Gerlinde uses her climbing fame to help a charity that supports poor children and orphans in Nepal.

If we look around at the things we’ve bought in our lives, we can easily notice that not all items get used properly. For example: a heavy wool coat that looked stylish even though we live in a tropical country, a phone that was put away when we bought the newest model, a car we only use on weekends, or a guest room turned into a storeroom.

In many cultures and over time, dreams have been linked to seeing the future. People believed these were messages from gods, giving them important information. Today, some people can remember dreaming about something that later happened in real life.

Big and expensive transportation projects in the world are about building bridges. Bridges are important connections that move cars, trucks, and trains across rivers and lakes, over mountains, or over other roads. Because of this, bridges are very important in civil engineering. Engineers carefully check them, especially when a bridge falls down.

After many weeks of problems, Gabriela wrote an email to her manager in Sweden about the issues with her team. Her manager asked if her team was working well and what she thought would help her work with her team members. Gabriela found her manager's questions too general and felt he wasn't solving the problems well.

Dogs that live in groups have learned that people give food to smaller, cute dogs. They send these dogs to ask for food for the whole pack. Some dogs use the city's metro to go from one part of their area to another. Scientists don't know how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their good sense of smell to recognize favorite places. Another idea is that they learn station names from announcements. Either way, metro passengers now see many dogs on trains, and locals do not pay much attention to them.

Ed Stafford from the UK was the first to walk the whole Amazon River. He began at a small stream in the Andes Mountains in Peru and ended at the river’s mouth in Brazil. It took him two years and four months to walk 6,000 kilometers. The Amazon rainforest has dangerous animals like snakes, crocodiles, and jaguars. Ed faced many risks but survived without serious injuries, though he had thousands of mosquito and ant bites.

In Britain, people spend over £1,000 on new clothes a year. This is about 4% of their income. This seems low, but it shows two big problems. Many use credit cards to buy clothes. Adults owe around £670 to credit card companies. That’s 66% of the clothing budget. People spend money they don’t have on things they don’t need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothes yearly. Most end in landfills.

Ed's journey would not have been possible without technology. He used a radio to ask for food and permission to cross the rainforest people's land. Many people came to help and guide him through difficult areas. Ed wrote a blog about his daily experiences. He used media attention about his trip to protest against rainforest damage and collect money for children and environmental charities in Brazil and Peru.

Many companies now understand how to make money through the sharing economy. They try to use resources that people aren't using enough. This popular business model uses online platforms to link customers with people who can offer a product or service. Companies like Airbnb help people rent out their unused rooms or houses for good money. Uber allows drivers to use their own cars to give rides and earn extra money in their free time.

Zoos help protect rare animals by helping them have babies. In the wild, these animals have a hard time finding partners. Poachers, habitat loss, and predators are dangers they face. A good zoo gives them a safe place to live and have babies. When wild populations get too small, their genes can become too much the same. Sending zoo-bred animals back to the wild can make their genes more different.

These accidents are very rare. Boats and trains can cause bridge collapses for different reasons. Trains hit bridges with high speed, while boats use their heavy weight, even when moving slowly. To prevent this, plan ahead. Use technology to find weak parts in bridges, make work areas safer, and design better bridges. This can reduce these bad accidents.

At first, Pi is very scared of the animals and jumps into the sea. Then he remembers there are hungry sharks nearby and knows he must climb back onto the lifeboat. The animals on the lifeboat fight and eat each other. Soon, only Pi and the tiger remain. The tiger, named Richard Parker, feels sick on the sea and does not want to eat Pi right now.

When Pi is 16, a new government comes to power. His parents disagree with it, so they close the zoo and decide to emigrate to Canada. Some animals are sold to North American zoos, and the family travels by ship with them. A heavy storm hits during the journey, causing the ship to sink. Unfortunately, Pi's family and the sailors drown, but he survives in a lifeboat with a hyena, zebra, orang-utan, and large tiger.

The Hunger Games had a lot of success since 2008 when Suzanne Collins wrote it. The book is available in 26 languages and sold millions of copies around the world. Collins was the first author for young readers to sell over one million e-books. It is now a popular Hollywood movie and made $152.5 million in its first weekend in North America alone.

Dreams might be a way our mind puts together the ideas from the day, but they show up in dreams with hidden meaning. When we are awake, we mostly think in words, like having talks with ourselves. When we sleep, the part of the brain for language is less active and the part for feelings is more active.

Good relationships are important for happiness. A study showed that most happy people have close friends and family and spend time with them often. It is helpful to talk about personal feelings with at least one person. Friends to play or chat with are not enough. Talking deeply is more important. Listening well can help build stronger connections.

Carol Dweck, a psychologist who encourages growth mindset, said the brain can change. People can learn skills and get better at them, even if they are difficult when you start. Many people praise the result or natural talents, for example: 'You see details well' or 'You organize events well.' But research shows that praising effort, trying new ways, and solving problems helps people learn and improve.

The rover checks the air often. In 2014, it found methane. Methane is a simple compound in natural gas. It does not stay in the air for very long. So, something on Mars is making new methane. NASA says Mars releases a lot each time. Methane levels go up and down with the seasons, as if the planet is breathing it in and out.

At the start of her career, Stanford psychologist Carol Dweck gave ten-year-olds problems a little too hard. One group reacted positively, saying they loved challenges and knew they could improve. She called this a 'growth mindset' focused on future goals. Another group felt their intelligence was judged and they had failed. These children had a 'fixed mindset' and couldn't imagine getting better. Some might cheat later, others looked for kids who did worse to feel better about themselves.

Horror movies use places that are empty or abandoned, like old hospitals, lonely houses, or ghost towns. These places feel scary because they are quiet. People wonder why they were left empty and what happened there. Directors choose them because the phone signals are weak, so nobody can call for help.

In horror films, basements are often scary. They are dark and sometimes damp. A narrow staircase leads to them. Usually, there is something or a bad person hiding there. Basements feel creepy even when empty.

Gary Collins was not on duty when he saw the London riots on TV. He saw people he recognized and stopped his holiday to help identify them. For six months, he watched CCTV videos and found 190 people, many by looking at their eyes. His work helped the investigation a lot. Even with 200,000 hours of footage, facial recognition software found only one person.

I find it interesting to think about how we can make human evolution go faster by improving our bodies. Imagine putting a computer in your brain! Soon this will be possible and we can improve math skills, seeing and hearing better, and our memory. This idea will become more common in the future.

It was an interesting talk. The speaker made good points. For parental influence, how can we expect teenagers not to text while working on homework if they see their parents using social media when cooking dinner or waiting at a red light? She talked about how people want to be in two or more places at once. They go back and forth between real-life chats and online messages. I often see this with my teenage daughter and her friends. They plan to meet but just sit in silence as they each talk online.

News stories about violence in the world can give us some hope. After World War II and before 1990, 30 wars caused over 100,000 deaths each. Now, while civil wars still exist, countries generally live in peace more than before. Terrorism has increased recently. Since World War II, wars have killed more civilians than soldiers. However, the situation for civilians isn't completely negative. While violent crimes cause more deaths than political conflicts, the global murder rate dropped from 8 per 100,000 in 2000 to 5.3 in 2015.

Wasfia has spent her life supporting human rights. In Bangladesh, she has seen many projects try to help women and girls learn and grow, but many times these projects end and they have nothing. Wasfia realized Bangladesh needed to show strength, so she combined her love for climbing mountains with human rights work. She began climbing in Tibet and Nepal, where mountains are common, because in Bangladesh most people have never seen one. People in her country and around the world are now noticing her efforts.

Many people believe that developing countries face serious problems such as extreme poverty, strict leaders, and lack of hope for change. However, this is not accurate. A great transformation is taking place. In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have improved their incomes and left poverty. Additionally, six million fewer children die each year from diseases, and millions more girls are attending school. Clean water is now available to many more people.

Many managers try to add positive comments before and after negative feedback to make it better. But if this becomes a common habit, employees might start thinking that the positive parts are just a way to make the bad messages easier to hear, which makes the good comments less meaningful. Instead, managers should give positive feedback to really support and encourage good work. This is more helpful than just using it to hide the negatives.

I support the campaign against killer robots. Scary robot movies show them as mean, but right now, military machines like drones and robot weapons are killing people with little help from humans. The next step might be machines that can decide who to hurt. This sounds very dangerous and not right. We must be careful about the tasks we give to machines.

More people learn English compared to all other languages together. English is spoken in the most countries in the world. Chinese has the largest number of native speakers by far. There seems to be a limited relationship between native speaker count and learner numbers. However, learner numbers are more closely connected to the number of countries where the language is spoken.

Your manager calls you into her office and wants to talk about your work on the last project. You are worried all weekend and think about what mistakes you might have made. On Monday morning, when you go into her office, she starts by saying you did well. You wonder if this is part of the usual feedback method called the 'feedback sandwich'. This method means: start with good news, mention any problems, end with good news again.

Born in the USA is an upbeat rock album. The lyrics have strong emotions. The catchy rock songs talk about the darker parts of the American dream. They focus on ordinary people who work hard but feel life gives them no success or recognition. For example, 'Glory Days' is about people in a small town remembering when they were young and full of hope. 'Downbound Train' tells about a young man who loses his job and faces big problems. The artist clearly writes about real people he knew and his own life if he hadn’t become famous. This album shows Bruce Springsteen’s unique and special talent.

Lewis wants more protected ocean areas—10% instead of 3%—to fix the harm from human actions like fishing too much, pollution, and trash. During his trips to the sea, Lewis has seen this damage directly. He has seen coral reefs turning white because of warmer water temperatures and lifeless areas near the Red Sea filled with plastic. Pugh thinks nature can heal if we let it, but time is running out. If we don't take care of our oceans soon, we might face a problem that's too hard to fix.

Terrie Sharp is a best-selling author. She has won the Olive Crime Writer Award two times. She was born in Glasgow in a place with a lot of crime. She learned to stay quiet, avoid trouble, and open car doors with a knife. She only uses this knowledge to write her books. Now she talks on shows like Police Today and goes to writing conferences across the UK.

Is life getting worse each day? Can we make progress? In his book Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker shows that life is getting better. People live longer, healthier, freer and happier today. Pinker says the big problem is that some people are trying to hurt reason and science. When leaders use group loyalty, belief that nothing can change, and distrust, they can cause big damage to democracy and global help between countries.

In old horror movies, the main characters could not or found it very hard to call for help or the police when they were in trouble. Today, mobile phones make this harder to believe. How do filmmakers keep the tension? No phone signal! If you are the hero in a horror film, it’s almost always true that when you need to call for help, there’s no signal. Sometimes the phone runs out of power during the call, or there's no signal.

In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America were losing their main banana, the Gros Michel. Now, the same problem is happening with the new banana, the Cavendish. Gros Michel bananas have thick peels and a sweet flavor. This made them easy to transport. The main company, United Fruit, grew their bananas quickly by taking cuttings from plants. They planted the crops in crowded fields.

Spiders have poison to catch their food. This poison does not hurt people. There are 40,000 kinds of spiders, but only 25 are dangerous to humans. A spider bite can cause pain, but it is not deadly. In Australia, the Sydney funnel-web spider is dangerous. However, antivenom has made it safe since 1981. Be careful with tarantulas. When they feel threatened, they throw small hairs. These hairs can cause itching or pain in the skin or eyes.

This horror film typical thing was very common in horror films from the 1900s to 1999. A group of teenagers have fun at the start, and by the end, all are dead except one girl. At the beginning, the girl is usually kind, shy, and not very strong. By the end, she becomes the strongest and most clever person. The girl almost always wins at the end.

To understand where our complex language came from, we need to compare human brains with those of other animals. It’s not just about brain size. Human brains developed new abilities over time. Objects from early humans don’t show the sounds they could make. Around 100,000 years ago, humans had a mouth, throat, and tongue that could make complex sounds. Before that, scientists can only guess how they communicated.

Society, not nature, decides that girls should prefer arts and humanities. Boys are expected to do math and physics. Young people rarely see women doing science jobs in TV or books. Many stories show scientists, inventors, or astronauts as men. Some girls think science workers are boring, lonely, and not good with people. This is not true, but it can make girls feel science is not for them. Seeing more women in science roles could help girls feel more confident and welcome in these subjects.

The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed for free in university buildings, with approximately 10,000 student readers. It is written and produced completely by students. A survey shows university students and staff value it greatly for fun, culture, and gaining work experience. Printing the newspapers costs a lot of money. Also, some students find it hard to get the paper because they need to visit the university in person. Another environmental problem is that many copies become litter on campus.

We have a yearly employee turnover rate of 12%. This is higher than the industry average of 7%. The main goal of this report is to find out why employees are engaged and provide suggestions to improve their work experience and keep more employees.

The speaker's words made sense to me. I think getting more connected can make people feel more alone. This isn't a big problem for my generation because we lived without tech before. We know how to be alone and understand it's OK. Young people under 20 are different. They talk a lot through messages and never feel alone. They might miss learning to enjoy being alone. They learn to chat using messages they can edit, but forget real talks that happen face-to-face.

Don't always give negative feedback after positive. If you always mix positive and negative, the good parts may be ignored. Sometimes, just give positive feedback because it's good. Avoid adding criticism unless needed.
